lg.l: akaṉaka rellā marumpaviḻ mullai
nikarmalar nelloṭu tūuyp pakaṉmāynta
mālai maṇiviḷakkaṅ kāṭṭi yiraviṟkōr
kōlaṅ koṭiyiṭaiyār tāṅkoḷḷa mēlōrnāḷ
mālati māṟṟāṇ makavukkup pālaḷikkap
pālvikkip pālakaṉ ṟāṉ cōra mālatiyum
pārppā ṉoṭumaṉaiyā ḷeṉmēṟ paṭātaṉaviṭ
ṭēṟpaṉa kūṟāreṉ ṟēṅki makakkoṇ
ṭamarar tarukkōṭṭam veḷyāṉaik kōṭṭam
pukarveḷḷai nākartaṅ kōṭṭam pakal vāyil
uccik kiḻāṉkōṭṭa mūrkkōṭṭam vēṟkōṭṭam
vaccirak kōṭṭam puṟampaṇaiyāṉ vāḻkōṭṭam
nikkantak kōṭṭa nilākkōṭṭam pukkeṅkum
tēvirkā ḷemmuṟunōy tīrmeṉṟu mēviyōr
pācaṇṭac cāttaṟkup pāṭu kiṭantāḷuk
kēcum paṭiyō riḷaṅkoṭiyā yācilāy
ceytava millōrkkut tēvar varaṅkoṭār
poyyuraiyē yaṉṟu poruḷuraiyē kaiyiṟ
paṭupiṇantā veṉṟu paṟittavaḷkaik koṇṭu
cuṭukāṭṭuk kōṭṭattut tūṅkiruḷiṟ ceṉṟāṅ
kiṭupiṇan tiṉṉu miṭākiṉip pēy vāṅki
maṭiyakat tiṭṭāṇ makavai yiṭiyuṇṭa
maññaipō lēṅki yaḻutāḷuk kaccāttaṉ
aññainī yēṅki yaḻaleṉṟu muṉṉai
uyirkkuḻavi kāṇāyeṉ ṟakkuḻavi yāyōr
kuyiṟpotumpar nīḻaṟ kuṟuka vayirppiṉṟi
māyak kuḻavi yeṭuttu maṭittiraittut
tāykaik koṭuttāḷat taiyalā ṭūya
maṟaiyōṉpiṉ māṇiyāy vāṉporuṭ kēḷvit
tuṟaipō yavarmuṭinta piṉṉa riṟaiyōṉum
tāyattā rōṭum vaḻakkuraittut tantaikkum
tāyarkkum vēṇṭum kaṭaṉkaḻittu mēyanāḷ
tēvanti yeṉpāṇ maṉaivi yavaḷukkup
pūvanta vuṇkaṇ poṟukkeṉṟu mēvittaṉ
mūvā viḷanalaṅ kāṭṭiyeṅ kōṭṭattu
nīvā veṉavuraittu nīṅkutalun tūmoḻi
ārtta kaṇava ṉakaṉṟaṉaṉ pōyeṅkum
tīrttat tuṟaipaṭivē ṉeṉṟavaṉaip pērttiṅṅaṉ
mīṭṭut taruvā yeṉavoṉṟaṉ mēliṭṭuk
kōṭṭam vaḻipāṭu koṇṭiruppāḷ vāṭṭaruñcīrk
kaṇṇaki nallāḷuk kuṟṟa kuṟaiyuṇṭeṉ
ṟeṇṇiya neñcat tiṉaiyaḷāy naṇṇi
aṟuku ciṟupuḷai nelloṭu tūuyc ceṉṟu
peṟuka kaṇavaṉō ṭeṉṟāḷ peṟukēṉ
kaṭukkumeṉ ṉeñcaṅ kaṉaviṉā leṉkai
piṭittaṉaṉ pōyōr perumpatiyuṭ paṭṭēm
paṭṭa patiyiṟ paṭāta toruvārttai
iṭṭaṉa rūrā riṭutēḷiṭ ṭeṉṟaṉmēl
kōvalaṟ kuṟṟatōr tīṅkeṉ ṟatukēṭṭuk
kāvalaṉ muṉṉaryāṉ kaṭṭuraittēṉ kāvalaṉō
ṭūrkkuṟṟa tīṅkumoṉ ṟuṇṭā luraiyāṭēṉ
tīkkuṟṟam pōluñ ceṟitoṭīi tīkkuṟṟam
uṟṟēṉō ṭuṟṟa vuṟuvaṉō ṭiyāṉuṟṟa
naṟṟiṟaṅ kēṭki ṉakaiyākum poṟṟoṭīi
kaittāyu mallai kaṇavaṟ korunōṉpu
poyttāy paḻampiṟappiṟ pōykkeṭuka vuyttuk
kaṭaloṭu kāviri ceṉṟalaikku muṉṟiṉ
maṭalaviḻ neytalaṅ kāṉaṟ ṟaṭamuḷa
cōmakuṇṭañ cūriya kuṇṭan tuṟaimūḻkik
kāmavēḷ kōṭṭan toḻutār kaṇavaroṭu
tāmiṉ puṟuva rulakattut taiyalār
pōkañ cey pūmiyiṉuñ pōyppiṟappar yāmorunāḷ
āṭutu meṉṟa vaṇiyiḻaikkav vāyiḻaiyāḷ
pīṭaṉ ṟeṉavirunta piṉṉarē nīṭiya
kāvalaṉ pōluṅ kaṭaittalaiyāṉ vantunam
kōvala ṉeṉṟāḷōr kuṟṟiḷaiyāḷ kōvalaṉum
pāṭamai cēkkaiyuṭ pukkuttaṉ paintoṭi
vāṭiya mēṉi varuttaṅkaṇ ṭiyāvum
calampuṇar koḷkaic calatiyo ṭāṭik
kulantaru vāṉporuṭ kuṉṟan tolainta
ilampāṭu nāṇut tarumeṉak keṉṉa
nalaṅkēḻ muruva ṉakaimukaṅ kāṭṭic
cilampuṟa koṇmeṉac cēyiḻai kēḷic
cilampu mutalākac ceṉṟa kalaṉō
ṭulantaporu ḷīṭṭuta luṟṟēṉ malarntacīr
māṭa maturai yakattucceṉ ṟeṉṉōṭiṅ
kēṭalar kōtā yeḻukeṉṟu nīṭi
viṉaikaṭaik kūṭṭaviyaṅ koṇṭāṉ kaṅkuṟ
kaṉaicuṭar kālcīyā muṉ.
As ladies with creeper-waists scattered
Flowers that rivaled the Mullai jasmine whose buds open
Along with paddy [grains] all over [their] wide mansions,
Having showed sapphire lamps [in] the evening
In which the daytime vanished,
As they each took on [on] a garb [appropriate] for the evening,
On the previous day, as Mālati provided milk to the child of [her] rival wife,
Having choked [on] the milk, the child slipping away [into death],
Mālati, lamenting, saying, ‘the lady of the Pārppāṉ’s house,
Leaving out [the fact that she would narrate] those things that did not happen,
They will not say acceptable things’ taking the young one,
Entering the Amarartaru temple, the Veḷyāṉai temple,
The temple of Pukarveḷḷainākar, the temple of Uccikkiḻāṉ
[With] a morning entrance, the temple of the village,
The temple of the spear, the temple of Vacciram,
The temple in which Puṟampaṇaiyāṉ lives,
The Nikkantam temple [and] the Nilā temple [respectively],
Everywhere, reaching [those places], saying, ‘Oh, Lords!
You must eliminate our sorrow!’, to she who lay recumbent to
He of the Pācaṇṭa treatise, [Iṭākiṉi, the demoness]
Saying, ‘Oh you [who is like] a young creeper! Oh you who is faultless,
The gods do not give boons to those without making penance.
It is not a false word. It is a word of wealth [=truth].
Give the corpuse that has fallen in [your] hand.’
Plucking [the baby off her hand], taking her [Mālati’s] hand,
Having gone to a cremation ground enclosure in the looming darkness,
[That] demoness [called] Iṭākiṉi that eats corpses that are placed there,
Taking [the child], put the child inside [her] stomach. Crying [out]
Like a peacock that had eaten thunder, that Cāttaṉ saying to her who cried,
‘Mother, you do not cry, having lamented’. Saying, ‘Don’t you see
The living infant in front [of you]?’,
[The demoness] becoming that baby [which died],
Nearing the shade in a grove of Koels,
Taking the magical infant without a doubt,
Raising it to [he] stomach [= lap],
That woman gave [the baby] to the hands of the mother.
[That baby], becoming the student after he of the pure Vedas,
Completing [= going to the other side] of the lessons on heavily matters,
After he completed [that], that Lord [= the baby as an adult],
Explaining the [appropriate] behaviour to the father and maternal uncle,
Completing the duties that were necessary to the father and to the mother,
On a suitable day, Desiring [for] her - [his] wife called Tēvanti - saying,
‘May [your] kohl-rimmed eyes to which flowers come bear [this sight]’,
He, having showed [her] [his] unaging, young beauty [= his immortal form],
Saying, ‘You come to my temple’, upon abandoning [her], the husband
The husband who was bound to pure words leaving as one who went away,
[The wife], saying, ‘ I will reside in holy ghats everywhere’, [and]
Putting upon one entity [the request], ‘You will give him back in such a way’,
Taking [on] the way of worship of the temple,
Saying, ‘There is a difficulty for she who is good - Kaṇṇaki - ,
Of an excellence that is difficult to fade’, approaching [Kaṇṇaki]
As she who is such, with a heart that considered [this matter],
Sprinkling Aṟuku grass [and] Ciṟupuḷai grass along with paddy,
Going [to her], she said, ‘May you obtain [happiness] with [your] husband.’
She, having heard that which was said, [namely],
‘My heart that is confused will not obtain [happiness],
Because of a dream. The one who held my hand, having gone
To one big city, we suffered. In the city in which we suffered,
The people of the town put [out] a word [= a rumour]
Of something that did not happen. Having placed
The stinging scorpion upon me, a certain harm is done to Kōvalaṉ’,
I spoke a bunch [of words] before the guardian [= king].
There is indeed a harm that befalls the town, along with [its] guardian.
I will not engage in speaking [of it].
‘Oh, you with close-set bangles! It seems it is a mistake!
If you hear the good reason for I having suffered
Along with the strong one who suffered [=my husband]
Along with me who experienced a fiery calamity,
It will be a laughing [matter to you]. Oh you with gold bangles!
You are not one who must be distressed. You failed [to perform]
[But] one [ritual] observance for [your] husband in your previous birth.
Let it be gone. Going to the Kāviri along with the sea that leads [its course],
At the frontyard in which [the waves] slap, inside those that are
[At] the shore [with] a seashore grove with blue waterlilies
In which palmyra [fronds] open,
Submerging [= bathing] in the tanks of Cūriya and Cōma Kuṇṭams at [that] ghat,
Those who worship in the temple of Lord Kāma will have pleasure
With their husbands on this earth. [Such] ladies, having gone
To the earth that makes pleasure for them, will be born [there]
We [too] shall play them one day.’
To she with beautiful jewels who said [all of this],
That perfect, young lady said, ‘This is not great [= right]’. After having been [so],
One young lady of speech [= announcements] said, ‘[Here is] our Kōvalaṉ,
Having come as he who was at the entrance, like a guardian’.
Kōvalaṉ too, having entered into the bed[room] that was befitting of song,
Seeing the suffering of her [Kaṇṇaki’s] faded body with green-gold bracelets,
Saying, ‘having dallied with a liar with principles that unite with all manner of deceit,
The poverty of having lost the hill of sky-high wealth that the family gave [us]
Gives shame to me’. [Kaṇṇaki], showing a smiling face of beauteous lustre,
Saying, ‘The anklets are there. Take [them].’
[Kōvalaṉ], saying, Oh you with perfect jewels! Listen:
I have decided to amass the wealth that was lost,
Along with the jewels that are gone. Going to Maturai
With storeyed buildings in which excellence blossomed,
You with a garland in which petals open! Move up [there with me!]’,
[Thus], as Karma came to a conclusion, he took the order, having extended [its powers],
Before the rays [= legs] of the instense sun swept away the night.
